title: 105_hr2485
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Superfund Liability Relief Act of 1997" provides small party liability relief under Superfund. The "Common Sense Superfund Liability Relief Act of 1997" amends Section 107(a) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to provide liability exemption for a person from whom a release or threatened release of a hazardous substance causes response costs. The "Common Sense Superfund Liability Relief Act of 1997" amends Section 107(a) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to provide liability exemption for a person who does not impede response actions or natural resource restoration at a facility, and who arranged for disposal or treatment of municipal solid waste or sewage sludge owned by them and meets certain criteria such as being the owner of residential property, a small business, or a small non-profit organization. The term 'small business' is defined as any business with up to 100 employees, as per the Small Business Act. SEC. 3. INNOCENT LANDOWNER PROTECTION UNDER SUPERFUND. Innocent Landowner Protection under Superfund: Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act to require an environmental site assessment for real property acquisition within 180 days prior to purchase. The assessment must meet specific standards set by the American Society for Testing. The President shall issue or designate alternative standards for environmental site assessments in real property transfers, following a study of commercial and industrial practices. These standards must meet specific requirements and be deemed commercially reasonable and generally accepted. The President shall consider various requirements for environmental site assessments in real property transfers, including interviews with stakeholders and reviewing historical sources to determine previous uses of the property. The environmental site assessment for real property transfers involves reviewing topographic maps, street directories, building department records, zoning/land use records, and other sources to identify past property uses. It also includes checking for recorded environmental cleanup liens and reviewing government records of sites likely to cause contamination. The environmental site assessment for real property transfers involves reviewing various records to identify past property uses and potential contamination sources. This includes examining landfill and disposal location records, underground storage tank records, hazardous waste handler and generator records, spill reporting records, and other government environmental records. Additionally, a visual site inspection of the property and adjacent properties is conducted to investigate hazardous substance practices. The environmental site assessment for real property transfers involves reviewing various records to identify past property uses and potential contamination sources. Factors considered include specialized knowledge of the landowner, purchase price compared to property value, ascertainable information about the property, obviousness of contamination, and record accessibility for review. The environmental site assessment requires maintaining a compilation of reviewed information, exercising care with hazardous substances, and providing cooperation and facility access. The curr_chunk discusses providing cooperation, assistance, and facility access for response actions or natural resource restoration at a facility. It also includes a cross-reference amendment to specify requirements for all appropriate inquiry. PROSPECTIVE PURCHASER PROTECTION UNDER SUPERFUND. Limitations on liability for prospective purchasers under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 are outlined in subsection (p). Prospective purchasers will not be liable if their liability is based solely on subsection (a)(1) and they do not impede response actions or natural resource restoration at a facility. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 limits liability for prospective purchasers under subsection (p). A new subsection (q) allows the United States to have a lien on a facility for unrecovered response costs if the owner is not liable under subsection (p). The lien amount shall not exceed the increase in fair market value of the property due to the response action. The new subsection (q) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 allows the United States to have a lien on a facility for unrecovered response costs. The lien arises when costs are first incurred and continues until satisfaction of the lien or recovery of all response costs. Conditions include carrying out a response action with unrecovered costs and considering fair market value. The definition of a "bona fide prospective purchaser" under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is a person who acquires ownership of a facility after a certain date and can prove certain criteria. The definition of a "bona fide prospective purchaser" under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 includes requirements for disposal prior to acquisition and conducting appropriate inquiry into previous ownership and uses of the facility. Compliance with ASTM standards or alternative standards designated by the President is necessary. Residential property purchased by a noncommercial entity requires a site inspection and title search with no further investigation needed. Legally required notices must be provided for any hazardous substances discovered or released at the facility. Appropriate care must be taken to stop ongoing releases of hazardous substances. The person must stop ongoing releases, prevent future releases, and limit exposure to hazardous substances. They must cooperate with authorized persons for response actions at the facility. The person is not liable for the relationship. The person is not liable for response costs at the facility due to any direct or indirect familial, contractual, corporate, or financial relationship.
